TypeSignature.Value: public sealed class Region : MarshalByRefObject, IDisposable
.class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit Region extends System.MarshalByRefObject implements class System.IDisposable

Docs.summary: Describes the interior of a graphics shape composed of rectangles and paths. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A region is scalable because its coordinates are specified in world coordinates. On a drawing surface, however, its interior is dependent on the size and shape of the pixels representing it. An application can use regions to clip the output of drawing operations. These regions are called clipping regions. For more information on using regions for clipping, see [How to: Use Clipping with a Region](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
An application can also use regions in hit-testing operations, such as checking whether a point or a rectangle intersects a region. For more information on using regions for hit-testing, see [How to: Use Hit Testing with a Region](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
An application can fill a region by using the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics.FillRegion%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method and a <xref:System.Drawing.Brush> object.
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.RegionData.Data%2A> from one <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.RegionData> object to set the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.RegionData.Data%2A> for another <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.RegionData>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#13](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.drawing.region_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#13](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.drawing.region_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#13](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.drawing.region_1.vb)]

## Remarks This method creates a new <xref:System.Drawing.Region> with a rectangular interior. The interior is defined by the `rect` parameter.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the Region constructor and <xref:System.Drawing.Region.MakeEmpty%2A> method. This example is designed to be used with Windows Forms. Create a form and paste the following code into it. Call the `FillEmptyRegion` method in the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event-handling method, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#7](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._13_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#7](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._13_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#7](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._13_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void Complement (System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath path);
.method public hidebysig instance void Complement(class System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath path) cil managed

Docs.param: The to complement this .
Docs.summary: Updates this to contain the portion of the specified that does not intersect with this .

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a rectangle and draws it to the screen in black.
- Creates a second rectangle that intersects with the first and draws it to the screen in red.
- Creates a region using the first rectangle.
- Creates a <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath>, and adds the second rectangle to it.
- Gets the complement of the region when combined with the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath>.
- Fills the complement area with blue and draws it to the screen.
Notice that the area of the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath> that does not intersect with the region is colored blue.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._7_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._7_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._7_1.cpp)]

.method public hidebysig instance void Complement(valuetype System.Drawing.Rectangle rect) cil managed

Docs.param: The structure to complement this .
Docs.summary: Updates this to contain the portion of the specified structure that does not intersect with this .

remarks.format: ## Examples For an example, see the <xref:System.Drawing.Region.Complement%28System.Drawing.RectangleF%29> method.

.method public hidebysig instance void Complement(valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF rect) cil managed

Docs.param: The structure to complement this .
Docs.summary: Updates this to contain the portion of the specified structure that does not intersect with this .

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a rectangle and draws it to the screen in black.
- Creates a second rectangle that intersects with the first and draws it to the screen in red.
- Creates a region using the first rectangle.
- Gets the complement of that region combined with the second rectangle.
- Fills the complement area with blue and draws it to the screen.
Notice that the area of the second rectangle that does not intersect with the region is colored blue.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._3_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._3_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#2](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._3_1.cpp)]

.method public hidebysig instance void Complement(class System.Drawing.Region region) cil managed

Docs.param: The object to complement this object.
Docs.summary: Updates this to contain the portion of the specified that does not intersect with this .

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a rectangle and draws it to the screen in black
- Creates a second rectangle that intersects with the first and draws it to the screen in red.
- Creates one region using the first rectangle and creates a second region using the second rectangle.
- Gets the complement of that first region when combined with the second region.
- Fills the complement area with blue and draws it to the screen.
Notice that the area of the second region that does not intersect with the first region is colored blue.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._1_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._1_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#3](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._1_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void Dispose ();
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Dispose() cil managed

Docs.summary: Releases all resources used by this .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Calling Dispose allows the resources used by this <xref:System.Drawing.Region> to be reallocated for other purposes.
Call Dispose when you are finished using the <xref:System.Drawing.Region>. The Dispose method leaves the <xref:System.Drawing.Region> in an unusable state. After calling Dispose, you must release all references to the <xref:System.Drawing.Region> so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the <xref:System.Drawing.Region> was occupying. For more information, see [Cleaning Up Unmanaged Resources](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md) and [Implementing a Dispose Method](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
> [!NOTE] > Always call Dispose before you release your last reference to the <xref:System.Drawing.Region>. Otherwise, the resources it is using will not be freed until the garbage collector calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Region> object's `Finalize` method.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the <xref:System.Drawing.Region.%23ctor%2A> constructor and the <xref:System.Drawing.Region.Exclude%2A> and Dispose methods.
This example is designed to be used with Windows Forms. Paste the code into a form and call the `FillRegionExcludingPath` method when handling the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cpp[System.Drawing.GraphicsProperties#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._9_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.GraphicsProperties#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._9_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.GraphicsProperties#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._9_1.cs)]

remarks.format: ## Remarks The current transformation of the graphics context `g` is used to compute the region interiors on the drawing surface.

[!code-cpp[System.Drawing.GraphicsProperties#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._12_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.GraphicsProperties#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._12_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.GraphicsProperties#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._12_1.cs)]

## Examples The following example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a rectangle and draws it to the screen in black
- Creates a second rectangle that intersects with the first and draws it to the screen in red.
- Creates a region using the first rectangle.
- Gets the nonexcluded area of the region when combined with the second rectangle.
- Fills the nonexcluded area with blue and draws it to the screen.
Notice that the area of the area of the region that does not intersect with the rectangle is colored blue.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#4](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._16_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#4](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._16_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#4](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._16_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Drawing.RectangleF GetBounds (System.Drawing.Graphics g);
.method public hidebysig instance valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF GetBounds(class System.Drawing.Graphics g) cil managed

Docs.param: The on which this is drawn.
Docs.summary: Gets a structure that represents a rectangle that bounds this on the drawing surface of a object.
Docs.returns: A structure that represents the bounding rectangle for this on the specified drawing surface.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The current transformation of the graphics context is used to compute the region interior on the drawing surface. The bounding rectangle is not always the smallest possible bounding rectangle depending on the current transformation.
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath> and adds an ellipse to it.
- Fills the path with blue and draws it to the screen.
- Creates a region that uses the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.GraphicsPath>.
- Gets the nonexcluded area of the region when combined with the second rectangle.
- Gets the bounding rectangle for the region and draws it to the screen in red.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#5](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._4_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#5](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._4_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#5](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._4_1.cpp)]

.method public hidebysig instance class System.Drawing.Drawing2D.RegionData GetRegionData() cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns a that represents the information that describes this .
Docs.returns: A that represents the information that describes this .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Drawing.Region> class allows you to define a custom shape. The shape can be made up of lines, polygons, and curves. GetRegionData describes the shape contained in this <xref:System.Drawing.Region>.
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.RegionData.Data%2A> from one <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.RegionData> object to set the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.RegionData.Data%2A> for another <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.RegionData>.

## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates the first rectangle and draws it to the screen in black.
- Creates the second rectangle and draws it to the screen in red.
- Creates a region from the first rectangle.
- Gets the area of intersection for the region when combined with the second rectangle.
- Fills the area of intersection with blue and draws it to the screen.
Notice that only the overlapped area for the region and rectangle is blue.

## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates the first rectangle and draws it to the screen in blue.
- Creates the second rectangle and draws it to the screen in red.
- Creates a region from the first rectangle.
- Determines if any portion of the rectangle intersects with the region.
- Displays the `true` or `false` result on the screen.
Notice that the rectangle intersects the region, so the result is `true`.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#8](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._5_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#8](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._5_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#8](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._5_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void MakeEmpty ();
.method public hidebysig instance void MakeEmpty() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes this to an empty interior.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Drawing.Region.%23ctor%2A> constructor and MakeEmpty method. This example is designed to be used with Windows Forms. Create a form and paste the following code into it. Call the `FillEmptyRegion` method in the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event-handling method, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#7](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._10_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#7](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._10_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#7](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._10_1.vb)]

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the MakeInfinite method. This example is designed to be used with Windows Forms. Create a form and paste the following code into it. Call the `FillEmptyRegion` method in the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event-handling method, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#8](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._11_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#8](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._11_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.MiscExamples#8](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._11_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void Transform (System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix matrix);
.method public hidebysig instance void Transform(class System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix matrix) cil managed

Docs.param: The by which to transform this .
Docs.summary: Transforms this by the specified .

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a rectangle and draws it to the screen in blue.
- Creates a region from the rectangle.
- Creates a transformation matrix and sets it to 45 degrees.
- Applies the transformation to the region.
- Fills the transformed region with red and draws the transformed region to the screen in red.
Notice that the red rectangle is rotated 45 degrees from the original rectangle, shown in blue.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#9](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._8_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#9](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._8_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#9](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._8_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void Translate (int dx, int dy);
.method public hidebysig instance void Translate(int32 dx, int32 dy) cil managed

Docs.param: The amount to offset this horizontally.
The amount to offset this vertically.
Docs.summary: Offsets the coordinates of this by the specified amount.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a rectangle and draws it to the screen in blue.
- Creates a region from the rectangle.
- Applies the translation to the region.
- Fills the translated region with red and draws the translated region to the screen in red.
Notice that the red rectangle is shifted down and to the right from the original rectangle, shown in blue.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#10](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._6_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#10](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._6_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#10](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._6_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void Translate (float dx, float dy);
.method public hidebysig instance void Translate(float32 dx, float32 dy) cil managed

Docs.param: The amount to offset this horizontally.
The amount to offset this vertically.
Docs.summary: Offsets the coordinates of this by the specified amount.

remarks.format: ## Examples For a code example, see theTranslate method.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates the first rectangle and draws it to the screen in black.
- Creates a second rectangle and draws it to the screen in red.
- Creates a region using the first rectangle.
- Gets the area of union for `myRegion` when combined with `complementRect`.
- Fills the fills the area of union with blue and draws it to the screen.
Notice that both rectangles are filled with blue, including the area of overlap.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#11](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._0_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#11](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._0_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#11](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._0_1.cpp)]

.method public hidebysig instance void Union(class System.Drawing.Region region) cil managed

Docs.summary: Updates this to the union of itself and the specified .

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates the first rectangle and draws it to the screen in black.
- Creates a second rectangle and draws it to the screen in red.
- Creates a region using the first rectangle.
- Gets the <xref:System.Drawing.Region.Xor%2A> area for `myRegion` when combined with `complementRect`.
- Fills the <xref:System.Drawing.Region.Xor%2A> area with blue and draws it to the screen.
Notice that both rectangles are filled with blue, except for the area of overlap.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#12](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.region._14_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#12](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.region._14_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRegionExamples#12](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.region._14_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Updates this to the union minus the intersection of itself with the specified .
